title: Reviewed: The Very Latest Active Noise-Canceling Wireless Headphones From JBL

|Mar 28, 2019,08:00am EDT

# Reviewed: The Very Latest Active Noise-Canceling Wireless Headphones From
JBL

[![Mark
Sparrow](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0edf9584c2d2373813deb913b5bd4cd1?s=400&d=mm&r=g)](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marksparrow/
"Photo of Mark Sparrow")

[Mark Sparrow](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marksparrow/)Senior Contributor

Opinions expressed by Forbes Contributors are their own.

[Consumer Tech](/consumer-tech)

Technology journalist specializing in audio, computing and photography

  * Share to Facebook
  * Share to Twitter
  * Share to Linkedin

The all-new JBL Live 650BTNC headphones are available in Black, White, and
Blue.

JBL

JBL has become a byword for wireless speakers in recent years, largely thanks
to the company’s range of excellent Bluetooth speakers that start with the
dinky little JBL Go model and carry on all the way up to the mighty Boombox.
All the JBL wireless speakers feature long battery life, many are waterproof,
and they sound great, too. No wonder JBL is one of the best-selling wireless
speaker brands on the market.

Now JBL is turning its attention to the Bluetooth headphone market with a new
range of new ‘Live’ models that it hopes will do as well as the company’s
range of Bluetooth speakers. A couple of weeks ago I got to spend some quality
time reviewing JBL’s new flagship wireless headphone before they were
announced to the public today so this may be one of the first reviews to be
published.

The JBL Live 650BTNC are an attractive pair of headphones that are available
white, black or blue finishes. Their styling has a bit of Beats about it and
looks pretty cool. However, what really stands out with this top-end pair of
wireless headphones is that they are Alexa and Google Assist compatible. You
get to choose which voice-assisted platform works for you and then you select
that in the JBL My Headphones app. Once set up, it’s a case of simply touching
either of the ear cups and issuing an order such as asking the time or
requesting your favorite radio station. It’s a neat solution and the first
pair of headphones I’ve seen that offers the choice of both Amazon's and
Google's platforms in a single model.

Most Popular In: [Consumer Tech](https://www.forbes.com/consumer-tech)

  * [

### Apple’s Surprise iPhone 12 Pro Upgrade Suddenly Confirmed

](https://www.forbes.com/sites/gordonkelly/2020/07/15/apples-iphone-12-pro-
max-ram-storage-upgrade-iphone-11-pro-max/)

  * [

### China’s Closed. So Google Invests $10 Billion In India, Following
Facebook, Amazon, Apple

](https://www.forbes.com/sites/johnkoetsier/2020/07/13/chinas-closed-so-
google-invests-10-billion-in-india-following-facebook-amazon-apple/)

  * [

### Apple Loop: New iPhone 12 Leaks, iPad Pro’s Massive Upgrade, Goodbye
MacBook Air

](https://www.forbes.com/sites/ewanspence/2020/07/13/apple-news-headlines-
iphone-12-leak-camera-ipad-pro-display-airpods-macbook-air-cancelled/)

The complete JBL Live 650BTNC package includes charging lead, headphone cable,
soft pouch, and... [+] headphones.

JBL

As well as looking cool, the JBL Live 650BTNC feel reasonably comfy when worn.
The fit is firm without making it feel like your head is being held in a
clamp. You could probably even jog wearing these headphones without fearing
they’d fall off. The headband is adjustable and padded, while the ear cushions
are made of a soft vinyl material that feels nice and didn’t make my ears feel
sweaty or uncomfortable. The earpads aren’t huge, so if you do have ears
approaching elephantine proportions, you might want to try them for size first
before committing to buy. The left-hand ear cup sports a Micro USB charging
port for topping up the Lithium-Ion battery, while the right-hand ear cup has
a power switch, volume controls, and a multi-function button for pausing
music, taking phone calls, or for skipping and repeating music tracks.
Finally, there’s a button for turning Bluetooth on or off, and another button
for switching between active noise-canceling and passive noise-canceling. It’s
all pretty easy to use and once you’ve committed the controls to muscle
memory, it’s easy to operate by touch alone.

The JBL Live 650BTNC are set up like most other Bluetooth headphones; you
simply pair them with your smartphone and begin streaming audio from up to 10
meters from your phone, tablet or computer. The headphones only need to be
paired once, then every time they’re turned on they will connect to your
streaming device. That’s all there is to it. With a fully charged battery,
which takes just a couple of hours to top up, these headphones can deliver up
to 20 hours of playing time, which is more than enough for a long return
flight across the Pacific. If the headphones are used without noise canceling
turned on, its' possible to get up to 30 hours of Bluetooth playtime.

As already mentioned, this flagship model from JBL incorporates an active
noise-canceling feature, which means it has built-in microphones that sample
any extraneous noises in the environment and then filters them out. The
headphones can be worn without playing music and used simply as a pair of
high-tech ear defenders, or they can be used to play music, making tunes much
easier to hear and appreciate as most of the surrounding noises are cut
dramatically. If you’ve never tried active noise-canceling headphones during a
flight or a railway journey, you’re missing a treat. It’s so much easier to
hear music without the horrendous background roar of jet engines spoiling the
music.

As a matter of course, the JBL Live 650BTNC headphones invoke the active
noise-canceling circuitry as soon as they’re powered up, but I’d quite like to
be able to change that default behavior as you don’t always want or need to
use active noise-canceling, especially if you’re at home in a quiet room. The
wireless Bluetooth function works well delivering a good quality of sound,
although there isn’t any support for the higher quality audio codecs such as
aptX and AAC. This is a bit of missed opportunity, in my opinion, and
something JBL ought to have included in order to better compete with other
models on the market that do support those codecs.

Although the higher quality codecs can be overkill when used in conjunction
with the active noise-canceling circuitry, if you’re just using the headphones
in Bluetooth mode, it would be nice to know you’re getting the best audio
quality possible rather than the bog-standard SBC protocol. Don’t get me
wrong, the SBC quality isn’t bad, it’s just that it could be even better. One
handy Bluetooth feature of the JBL Live 650BTNC is the multipoint facility
that enables two Bluetooth devices to connect to the headphones. And why on
earth would you want to connect two sources to the headphones? Simple… you
might have a work phone that you use to take business calls, while your music
may be on your personal smartphone or MP3 player. With multipoint, you can
have both connected to your headphones and take business calls on the
treadmill as well as listening to your exercise playlist.

The folding design of the JBL Live 650BTNC means the headphones take up less
space in your luggage... [+] or work bag.

JBL

The sound of these flagship wireless headphones from JBL is well balanced.
There’s enough bass for most people’s tastes and the treble is detailed enough
without being harsh or grating. The mid-range holds back just a little, but as
an all-round pair of headphones, the JBL Live 650BTNC strike the right balance
and will tick most people’s boxes. Incidentally, if the battery charge does
run out, it’s possible to plug the headphones into a standard 3.5mm stereo
jack output using the supplied audio cable. It’s then possible to carry on
listening to music, albeit without any noise canceling.

When it comes to the performance of the active noise-canceling circuitry, the
JBL Live 650BTNC headphones do a pretty good job. However, I’m not entirely
sure that they’re up there with the very best-in-class headphones from the
likes of [Bose](http://www.forbes.com/sites/marksparrow/2016/12/19/bose-has-
cut-the-cord-of-its-new-baby-the-qc35-bluetooth-noise-cancelling-headphones/),
[Sennheiser](http://www.forbes.com/sites/marksparrow/2017/07/16/can-
sennheisers-noise-cancelling-headphones-beat-the-mighty-bose-qc35/), and
[Sony](http://www.forbes.com/sites/marksparrow/2018/10/13/sonys-brand-new-
noise-canceling-headphones-reviewed-and-rated/) in terms of noise-blocking
efficacy and comfort. However, for most people’s needs, these headphones do
the job, and they do it well, at a price that’s affordable. The entire package
is really pleasing with a nice and small form factor, plus foldable ear cups
that make the headphones small enough to stow away in the supplied carrying
bag.

The new design of the JBL Live 650BTNC Bluetooth headphones will appeal to all
ages.

JBL

**Verdict:** These new and attractive JBL Live 650BTNC headphones offer good
wireless performance and effective active noise-cancelation at a price point
some 30% lower than the market-leading models from Bose and Sony. The styling
is good and the sound is more than adequate. Comfort may be an issue for some
people so it’s worth comparing them with the [Bose
QC35](http://www.forbes.com/sites/marksparrow/2016/12/19/bose-has-cut-the-
cord-of-its-new-baby-the-qc35-bluetooth-noise-cancelling-headphones/) and
[Sony’s WH1000XM3](http://www.forbes.com/sites/marksparrow/2018/10/13/sonys-
brand-new-noise-canceling-headphones-reviewed-and-rated/) models, which I
reviewed last year. Comfort is very important with headphones if you intend
wearing them for eight hours at a stretch. Not many models can pass that
comfort test for me. If you love that beefy JBL sound then you’ll love the new
JBL Live 650BTNC headphones. Well worth a closer look.

**Pricing:** $199.95 / £179

**More info:**[https://www.jbl.com/](https://www.jbl.com/wireless-
headphones/JBL+LIVE650BTNC.html?dwvar_JBL%20LIVE650BTNC_color=Black-USA-
Current#start=1)

**Specifications:**

  * Driver size: 40mm
  * Driver sensitivity at 1kHz/1mW: 100dB
  * Dynamic frequency response range: 16Hz–20kHz
  * Maximum input power: 30mW Impedance: 32 ohm
  * Bluetooth version: 4.2
  * Bluetooth transmitted power: 0-4 dbm
  * Bluetooth transmitted modulation: GFSK, π/4DQPSK, 8DPSK
  * Bluetooth frequency: 2.402GHz–2.48GHz Bluetooth profiles: HFP v1.6, A2DP V1.3, AVRCP V1.5
  * Battery type: Polymer Li-ion Battery (3.7VDC, 700mAh)
  * Charging time: 2hrs from empty
  * Music playtime with BT on: up to 30hrs Music playtime with BT on and NC on: 20hrs
  * Music playtime with BT off and NC on: 35hrs
  * Weight: 260g

The JBL Live 650BTNC supports both Amazon and Google voice assistants.

JBL

[![Mark
Sparrow](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0edf9584c2d2373813deb913b5bd4cd1?s=400&d=mm&r=g)](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marksparrow/
"Photo of Mark Sparrow")

[Mark Sparrow](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marksparrow/)

I’ve been a tech journalist for more than 35 years and I've written for both
Mac and PC computing titles as well as spending many years writing about
audio, imaging and

…

Read More

I’ve been a tech journalist for more than 35 years and I've written for both
Mac and PC computing titles as well as spending many years writing about
audio, imaging and digital cameras for a raft of tech publications. I enjoy
all aspects of technology, especially using gadgets that make life more
enjoyable, creative and productive. A large part of my time is spent hunting
down and testing some of the best and most innovative technology on the market
today.
